IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: Provide Christian ministry to junior & senior high school age youth of US military personnel.
IRS990.MissionDesc: The Mission of MCYM/Club Beyond is to: "Celebrate life with military teens, introduce them to the Life Giver, and help them become more like Him."
IRS990.Desc: Military Community Youth Ministries (MCYM) provides the Club Beyond program to the teen-aged children of U.S. Military Families stationed around the world. All program service expenses (which exclude management and fundraising expenses) function in direct support of providing the Club Beyond program to military teens at U.S. Military installations around the world. During this fiscal year, these program service expenses were used to bring MCYM's Club Beyond program to U.S. military installations located in a number of different countries on multiple continents. See Schedule O for continuation of program service accomplishments.

AccountActivitiesOutsideUSGrp.SpecificServicesProvidedTxt: Outreach to American military teens, in partnership with Young Life, through weekly clubs, special activities, and camps.
Outreach to American military teens, in partnership with Young Life, through weekly clubs, special activities, and camps.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Scholarship funds are tied directly to the status of a military student and their financial need. No cash changes hands - funds are applied directly to the student's account.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Travel for companions
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The CEO's spouse is an employee of Young Life, an unrelated organization to MCYM. She occasionally travels with the CEO for bona fide MCYM ministry purposes. These travel expenses are covered by MCYM and are not treated as compensation.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part III Form 990 Part VII, Section A, Line 5
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The compensation for Marty McCarty, CEO, was paid by Young Life, an organization unrelated to Military Community Youth Ministries (MCYM). The CEO works as a seconded employee for MCYM as a three-quarter time employee. His pro-rated compensation for the 2022 calendar year included salary of $91,094 and non-taxable benefits of $67,488 (which includes $26,685 in housing allowance). President/Secretary Phil Alfrey is also a seconded employee from YL. A total of $72,882 in wages and $75,701 in benefits (including a housing allowance of $28,128) was paid by YL for Phil's services rendered to the filing organization. The remaining portion of his wages was paid by MCYM via reimbursements to YL.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part II COMPENSATION FROM AN UNRELATED ORGANIZATION OR INDIVIDUAL
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: NAME - MR. MARTY MCCARTY, COMPENSATION FROM UNRELATED ORGANIZATION - 158582.000000, NAME OF UNRELATED ORGANIZATION - YOUNG LIFE, TYPE OF COMPENSATION - WAGES AND BENEFITS

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule J, Part II COMPENSATION FROM AN UNRELATED ORGANIZATION OR INDIVIDUAL
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: NAME - MR. PHIL ALFREY, COMPENSATION FROM UNRELATED ORGANIZATION - 148583.000000, NAME OF UNRELATED ORGANIZATION - YOUNG LIFE, TYPE OF COMPENSATION - WAGES AND BENEFITS

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part III, Line 4a Program Service Accomplishments Continued:
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The program is provided for American military teenagers of any race, color, creed, sex, age, disability, national origin, sexual orientation, or gender identity and is provided by responsible, trained, and screened adult MCYM staff and volunteer leaders, who reach out to military teens unconditionally as caring adult role models and mentors. Club Beyond is a faith-based, ecumenical program conducted in collaborative relationships with Military Chaplains at each location. The Club Beyond program provides teens with opportunities to participate in regular, safe, and well-supervised activities, such as weekly Club Beyond meetings, as well as periodic special events, which include but are not limited to weekend and week-long camp trips, work-service projects, and Bible studies. This fiscal year, the program was available to tens of thousands of military teenagers living at or near installations with Club Beyond programs. Club Beyond programs complement the work that military installation Chaplains and Commanders are engaged in to meet their responsibilities to serve and provide for their military family members. The Club Beyond program and its on-line and published resources align with and support a major goal of the U.S. Military: to build resiliency into Service Members and their Families. The expanding global network of Club Beyond programs is creating a "safe place" for military teens that serves as a source of stability and familiarity, as these teens frequently relocate with their parents, who are regularly transferred to U.S. Military duty stations around the world.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part V, Line 2a
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: MCYM does not file any W-2s as employees are hired through Young Life, an unrelated organization. MCYM reimburses Young Life for the employees' compensation related to the hours worked for MCYM and the reimbursements are reported on Form 990, Part VII, Section A and Form 990, Part IX, Lines 5 - 10. The number reported on this Line represents the number of employees who work 100% for MCYM.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 1a Delegate broad authority to a committee
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Executive committee has the power to act on behalf of the Board between meetings as necessary. The Committee distributes to all Board Members a report of its actions and activities at the next meeting of the Board. The Committee consists of the Chair, Vice Chair, CEO, and chairs of standing committees.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 11b Review of form 990 by governing body
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Form 990 was prepared by an independent CPA firm and reviewed by the CEO and the Treasurer in detail. The reviewed Form 990 is then provided to the board of directors prior to filing with the IRS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 12c Conflict of interest policy
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Treasurer reviews the Conflict of Interest policy annually for compliance with industry best practices and then management discusses. Disclosures are signed annually at the September board meeting by officers and directors. The Executive Committee monitors conflicts of interest throughout the year. When a conflict is identified, the Board member recuses themselves from the decision, or from the Board if necessary.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 15a Process to establish compensation of top management official
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Each year, the MCYM board of directors reviews the CEO's compensation package including benefits. The final decision is subject to a MCYM Board vote. Young Life consults with the members of the MCYM Executive Committee regarding compensation and shares the responsibility with MCYM to determine appropriate compensation. The CEO is ultimately an employee of Young Life and final compensation is subject to their approval. A real time compensation service is used to run comparability data on individuals holding similar positions within the region. The data is used as a the basis for determining the amount of compensation for the year. A representative of the MCYM board meets with and discusses compensation arrangements with an HR executive and representative of Young Life who also gathers comparability data for the Young Life compensation arrangements. Decisions and deliberations are documented in the Committee and/or Board minutes.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 15b Process to establish compensation of other employees
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Treasurer is also a seconded employee and is subject to the compensation policies of Young Life. MCYM pays reimbursements to Young Life for the services of the Treasurer. Young Life uses regional compensation data to help establish an appropriate pay scale. The independent members of the Young Life Board are responsible for the final approval of officer level salaries. Deliberations and decisions are documented in the Young Life Board minutes.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 19 Required documents available to the public
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The governing documents, conflict of interest policy, and financial statements are available upon request.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VII, Section A, Line 1a, Column (D) & Column (F); Sch J, Part II, Columns (B).
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Compensation reported in Part VII, column D and Schedule J, Part II, column B is the amount reported on the individual's W-2, box 1 for those employees who are qualified ministers. Employee deferrals to qualified retirement plans are normally captured in box 5, not box 1 of Form W-2. For reporting purposes we have included the minister's retirement plan deferrals in Part VII, column F and Schedule J, Part II, column C.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VIII, Line 11d Other Miscellaneous Revenue
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Other Income - Total Revenue: 3842, Related or Exempt Function Revenue: , Unrelated Business Revenue: , Revenue Excluded from Tax Under Sections 512, 513, or 514: 3842;

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part IX, Column (B)
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The IRS Form 990 instructions specifically state that donated services and facilities should be omitted from Form 990 reporting even though these amounts are required to be reported by generally accepted accounting principles. Thus, the value of these contributions are properly included in the audited financial statements of Military Community Youth Ministries in revenues and program expenses. Military Community Youth Ministries would prefer to include the value of donated services and facilities in the organization's Form 990. We believe this shows the reader a more complete and accurate picture of the financial activities of the organization for the year. Nevertheless, because of the IRS' specific requirements, contributions of donated services and facilities have not been reported as contribution revenue on Form 990, Part VIII, Line 1f. Correspondingly, the associated program expenses have not been reported in Form 990, Part IX, Column B. (You will find the reconciliation of the audited financial statements to Form 990 on Schedule D, Parts XI and XII, where these differences are enumerated.) If the amounts were included on Form 990, Program Service expenses (Form 990, Part IX, Column B) would increase by $2,403,228. In addition, revenues (Part VIII, Line 1f) would increase by the $2,403,228. More important to readers of Form 990, the functional expense percentages (as reported in the audited financial statements) should be as follows: PROGRAM SERVICE EXPENSES - 89.0% MANAGEMENT AND GENERAL EXPENSES - 9.2% FUNDRAISING - 1.8%

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part XI, Line 9 Other changes in net assets or fund balances
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Gain on Exchange Rate - 3761;
